hawaiian_text: A pau ka pule ‘ana a Nāmakaokapāo‘o, i ia wā i  ‘o‘oki ai ‘o Puali‘i i ke ko‘ilipi i luna pono o  Nāmakaokapāo‘o, e ho‘ohuli aku ā nā ‘oi o ke ko‘i  iā Puali‘i, moku ke po‘o, a ‘ōlelo mai i kahi ‘ē. Pane  mai ke po‘o o Puali‘i iā Nāmakaokapāo‘o: “Aloha  ‘oe, e Nāmakaokapāo‘o.” Lālau akula ‘o   Nāmakaokapāo‘o i ke po‘o o Puali‘i a kiola akula i  kai o Waipouli, he ana ma kahakai o Honouliuli, ‘o  kona loa, ‘elima mile ka loa.
qwen3-235b-a22b-think-parser-fireworks_t: When Nāmakaokapāoʻo finished praying, at that moment Pualiʻi cut off the thighbone of Nāmakaokapāoʻo and used it as a weapon, so that the very marrow of the bone turned against Pualiʻi and severed his head, and the head spoke from the ground. The head of Pualiʻi addressed Nāmakaokapāoʻo: "Aloha ʻoe, e Nāmakaokapāoʻo." Nāmakaokapāoʻo then grabbed Pualiʻi’s head and threw it into the sea cave at Waipouli, a cave at the seaside of Honouliuli, five miles long.
qwen3-235b-a22b-think-parser-fireworks_c:
**Paragraph 9:**  
• This passage escalates the conflict between Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o and his stepfather Pua-li'i, featuring **supernatural violence** and **spiritual retribution** central to Hawaiian oral storytelling:  
– **Disembodied speech** ("The head spoke from the ground") evokes the **surviving mana (spiritual power)** in severed body parts, a motif tied to ancient practices of ancestor veneration and posthumous communication. In traditional Hawaiian belief, the head (po'o) housed 'uhane (soul), and a severed head speaking signifies unresolved spiritual entanglement or curses (*anaana*). Pua-li'i's head addressing Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o with "Aloha 'oe" (a phrase later immortalized in Liliʻuokalani's song) juxtaposes **affectionate greeting** with **macabre irony**, suggesting sarcasm or a prophetic omen.  
– **Disposal of the head** by casting it into **Waipouli**, a coastal cave in Honouliuli (‘dark bay’), links to **ʻīlio (dog)** mythology: caves in *Ewa* district were believed to harbor ʻaumākua (family gods) in canine form that guarded sacred bones. By banishing the head "five miles long" (5-mile cave?), Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o asserts dominance over Pua-li'i’s spirit while ritually containing its threat.  
• **Symbolism of the thighbone (ko'ilipi)**:  
– The thighbone (ili in Hawaiian) symbolizes **genealogical strength** (koʻihonua = lineage), making Pua-li'i's use of it as a weapon a violation of ancestor veneration. Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o's transformation of the bone's marrow into an instrument of death reflects his **supernatural ability to subvert kinship ties**, a recurring theme in his mythos as an anti-ʻAi Kapu figure.  
• **Pua-liʻi's etymology**:  
– Pu-a-liʻi = "flower [plum blossom?] of the chief" – ironically marked by brutality rather than aristocratic gentility. His name and action parody the *moʻolelo* trope of **liʻi (chiefs) protecting their people**; instead, he attacks the demigod who could ensure abundance (via breaking the ʻAi Kapu).  
• **Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o's transcendence**:  
– Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o's mastery over life and death (decapitating Pua-li'i) and nature (casting the head into seacoast geology) positions him as a **liminal force** between human and divine domains. The honu-liuli (dark bay) setting, associated with Kane-milohaʻi's rainbows (*Kamakau 1870*), contrasts with the cave's darkness, symbolizing his **dual role as destroyer of the old order and herald of renewal**.  
– The **five-mile length** (loa, elima mile) may encode an astronomical reference: *honou* ("ring/enclosure") + *liuli* ("dark") suggests Polynesian astronomical knowledge of **dark nebulae** (like the Great Dark Rift), reflecting Hawaiian cosmology’s integration of myth and sky observation (*Kamakau: Na Kumu Hawaii*). This numeric emphasis (5 miles) aligns with sacred numbers in hula cosmology (5 = Lono deity’s cycle).  
• **Cultural allegory**:  
– The episode mirrors the collapse of *ʻAi Kapu*'s patriarchal hierarchy. Pua-li'i’s severed head = the dead weight of tradition; Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o’s disposal = symbolic rejection of ancestral tyranny. This aligns with Nā-maka’s role as sister-brothers (through mother Pō-ka-'ī) who transcend rigid class systems (*Beckwith 1951:57*).  
– Pua-li'i’s "Aloha ʻoe" directly anticipates 19th-century cultural tensions: using the same phrase in both *mele* and this mythical violence critiques **inauthentic displays of affection** under colonial shifts.

reference_translation: When Nāmakaokapāo‘o ended his prayer, Puali‘i  struck at Nāmakaokapāo‘o with the adze right on  top of his head, but the blade of the adze turned  towards Puali‘i and his head was cut off. From a  distance, the head of Puali‘i said to   Nāmakaokapāo‘o, “Goodbye, Nāmakaokapāo‘o.”  Nāmakaokapāo‘o took the head of Puali‘i and  threw it in the sea at Waipouli, a cave on the  beach at Honouliuli, which was five miles long.
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 9:**• While the abandonment of the ‘Ai Kapu and the rise  of Christianity are historical, Pua-li‘i’s attack of Nā- maka-o-ka-pāo‘o does not seem to have a correlating  historical reference. The ‘Ai Kapu was abandoned in  1819 and the first Christian missionaries arrived in  Hawai‘i in 1820, with a full year in the interum of no  organized religion to replace the ‘Ai Kapu. While  many Hawaiians were stubbon to adopt Christianity  and resented it, Christianity spread quickly and  overwhelmed any pro-‘Ai Kapu sentiment by the end  of the 1820s. If Pua-li‘i here represents the ‘Ai Kapu  and Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o represents Christianity, and  the adoption of Western culture in a more broad  sense, this event in the story seems to misrepresent  the ‘Ai Kapu as savage, impulsive, and violent against  Christianity, culminating in a single event. There is no  such historical single event recorded in history;  • By a twist of fate, the adze Pua-li‘i wielded to cut off  the head of Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o somehow turned  against the wielder, cutting off the head of Pua-li‘i,  which Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o tossed into the ocean at Wai-pouli (water of darkness), a cave in Hono-uliuli  (bay of darkness) in ‘Ewa, O‘ahu, a distance of five   miles away. This ironic demise of Pua-li‘i signifies the  ultimate defeat of the ‘Ai Kapu by Christianity and/or  progressive ambitions, but this violent event has no  parallel in Hawaiian history. This could be viewed as  an embellishment as a type of Christian progaganda.  • The five-mile long toss of Pua-li‘i’s head by  Nāmakaokapāo‘o was an emphasis on the boy’s  superhuman physical strength.
